articles.headline: Madoff Suits Add Details About Fraud
articles.snippet: Regulators have accused four people of knowingly steering billions of dollars into Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: Regulators have accused four people of knowingly steering billions of dollars into Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three lawsuits filed on Monday provided new details about what regulators say went on inside Bernard L. Madoff’s long-running Ponzi scheme, including information about who might have helped perpetuate the fraud for so long.

articles.headline: Despite Law, Job Conditions Worsen in China
articles.snippet: With China’s exports reeling and unemployment rising because of the global slowdown, there is growing evidence that factories are ignoring or evading a new contract labor law.
articles.abstract: With China’s exports reeling and unemployment rising because of the global slowdown, there is growing evidence that factories are ignoring or evading a new contract labor law.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONGGUAN, China  Liu Pan, a 17-year-old factory worker, was crushed to death last April when the machine he was operating malfunctioned.

articles.headline: Ideas Online, Yes, but Some Not So Presidential
articles.snippet: When the White House asked people to post ideas on open government on a new Web site, it heard about U.F.O.’s, marijuana and the president’s birth certificate.
articles.abstract: When the White House asked people to post ideas on open government on a new Web site, it heard about U.F.O.’s, marijuana and the president’s birth certificate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On Jan. 21, his first full day in office, President Obama promised to open up the government, ordering officials to use modern technologies like Internet message boards and blogs to give all Americans a bigger voice in public policy.

articles.headline: In a Death Seen Around the World, a Symbol of Iranian Protests
articles.snippet: The killing of Neda Agha-Soltan on Satuday has stirred wide outrage in a society that is infused with the culture of martyrdom.
articles.abstract: The killing of Neda Agha-Soltan on Satuday has stirred wide outrage in a society that is infused with the culture of martyrdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  It was hot in the car, so the young woman and her singing instructor got out for a breath of fresh air on a quiet side street not far from the antigovernment protests they had ventured out to attend. A gunshot rang out, and the woman, Neda Agha-Soltan, fell to the ground. “It burned me,” she said before she died.

articles.headline: Settlement Anticipated in UBS Case
articles.snippet: The bank argues that disclosing client names would cause it to violate Swiss financial secrecy laws and open its executives and bankers to prosecution in Switzerland.
articles.abstract: The bank argues that disclosing client names would cause it to violate Swiss financial secrecy laws and open its executives and bankers to prosecution in Switzerland.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department may drop a closely watched legal case aimed at forcing the Swiss bank UBS to divulge the names of 52,000 wealthy American clients suspected of offshore tax evasion, a United States official briefed on the matter said Monday. The move, which would halt an unusually aggressive effort to force Switzerland to lift its veil of banking secrecy, could happen by mid-July.

articles.headline: Family Loyalty Anchors Ford in Risky Times
articles.snippet: Descendants of Henry Ford still meet regularly, and play a crucial role in guiding the automaker through troubled times for the industry.
articles.abstract: Descendants of Henry Ford still meet regularly, and play a crucial role in guiding the automaker through troubled times for the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich.  They met in late January at a nondescript conference center near the Ford Motor Company’s headquarters, just as they have every three months for the last 20 years.

articles.headline: A Transplant That Is Raising Many Questions
articles.snippet: While there is no easy way to cheat the system, wealthy patients in need of organs have an advantage in being able to join many waiting lists.
articles.abstract: While there is no easy way to cheat the system, wealthy patients in need of organs have an advantage in being able to join many waiting lists.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reports that Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, traveled to Tennessee for a liver transplant about two months ago raise many questions  not just about his prognosis, but also about the system for allocating scarce organs to the many people who need them.
articles.byline: By Denise Grady and Barry Meier

articles.headline: Apple’s Obsession With Secrecy Grows Stronger
articles.snippet: Not even its chief executive’s liver transplant was enough to get Apple to break out of its secretive habits.
articles.abstract: Not even its chief executive’s liver transplant was enough to get Apple to break out of its secretive habits.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple is one of the world’s coolest companies. But there is one cool-company trend it has rejected: chatting with the world through blogs and dropping tidbits of information about its inner workings.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Web Pries Lid of Iranian Censorship
articles.snippet: Iran’s sometimes faltering attempts to come to grips with censorship in the 21st century are providing a laboratory for what can and cannot be done.
articles.abstract: Iran’s sometimes faltering attempts to come to grips with censorship in the 21st century are providing a laboratory for what can and cannot be done.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after Neda Agha-Soltan bled her life out on the Tehran pavement, the man whose 40-second video of her death has ricocheted around the world made a somber calculation in what has become the cat-and-mouse game of evading Iran’s censors. He knew that the government had been blocking Web sites like YouTube and Facebook. Trying to send the video there could have exposed him and his family.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Mexican Cartels Lure American Teens as Killers
articles.snippet: Drug cartels operate their smuggling and murder-for-hire rings on both sides of the the U.S.-Mexican border.
articles.abstract: Drug cartels operate their smuggling and murder-for-hire rings on both sides of the the U.S.-Mexican border.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAREDO, Tex.  When he was finally caught, Rosalio Reta told detectives here that he had felt a thrill each time he killed. It was like being Superman or James Bond, he said.
